['Dye: A substance used to color or tint fabric.', 'Weave: A method of creating fabric by interlacing two sets of yarns at right angles.', 'Knit: A process of creating fabric by looping yarn with needles.', 'Print: A technique for applying a design or pattern to fabric using ink or dye.', 'Embellish: To decorate or embellish textiles with features like sequins, beads, or embroidery.', 'Embroider: To decorate textiles with needle and thread, creating intricate designs and patterns.', 'Quilt: A textile made from layers of fabric stitched together to create a pattern or design.', 'Appliqu√©: A technique for attaching fabric pieces to a base fabric using sewing or iron-on adhesive.', 'Batik: A method of creating patterns on fabric by applying wax to areas before dyeing.', 'Tie-dye: A technique for creating patterns on fabric by tying or knotting threads in specific patterns before dyeing.', 'Resist: A substance used to prevent dye from penetrating certain areas of fabric, creating patterns and designs.', 'Lace: A delicate textile made from threads woven together to create intricate patterns.', 'Brocade: A luxurious textile made from gold or silver threads woven with silk or cotton.', 'Velvet: A soft, plush fabric made from dense piles of yarn.', 'Suzani: A type of embroidered textile originating from Central Asia and featuring intricate floral patterns.', 'Kente cloth: A traditional Ghanaian textile made from strips of dyed cotton woven together to create vibrant patterns.', 'Paisley: A pattern featuring intricate teardrop shapes and curved lines, often used in textiles and fabrics.', 'Chintz: A glazed calico fabric featuring colorful floral or figurative designs.', 'Toile: A lightweight, plain-woven fabric often used for dressmaking and quilting.', 'Linen: A natural fiber made from flax plants, commonly used in high-quality textiles and fabrics.']

['Here are some examples:', 'Lean manufacturing: This is a systematic approach to identifying and eliminating waste in all forms within an organization.', 'Six Sigma: It is a methodology for process improvement that seeks to minimize defects and variations in business practices.', 'Total Quality Management (TQM): Is a management approach aimed at ensuring that organizations continuously improve their processes and products to meet customer needs and expectations.', 'Kaizen: It is a Japanese philosophy that emphasizes continuous improvement of all aspects within an organization, including processes, products, and employee skills.', 'Just-in-time (JIT): A manufacturing strategy aimed at reducing waste by producing and delivering products only as needed.', 'Continuous Improvement: A methodology that encourages organizations to constantly look for ways to improve their operations, processes, and products.', 'Total Productive Maintenance (TPM): Is a maintenance approach that emphasizes the importance of preventive maintenance and empowering operators to take ownership of equipment reliability.', 'Cellular manufacturing: It is a production technique that involves organizing machines and workstations into cells to increase efficiency and reduce waste.', 'Flexible Manufacturing System (FMS): A computer-controlled system that can efficiently produce a wide range of products with minimal setup time.', 'Material requirements planning (MRP): It is a production planning and inventory control system used to manage manufacturing processes.', 'Supply chain management: This involves coordinating and managing all activities involved in the production and delivery of a product, from raw material sourcing to distribution.', 'Kanban: Is a visual system for managing work that emphasizes continuous improvement and limiting WIP (work in progress) to optimize efficiency.', 'Agile manufacturing: It is an approach that emphasizes flexibility and adaptability, allowing organizations to respond quickly to changing market conditions and customer preferences.', 'Design for Manufacturability (DFM): A design approach that considers the manufacturing process when creating a product, resulting in easier, more efficient production.', 'Production planning: This includes scheduling, resource allocation, and quality control to ensure products are delivered on time and meet customer expectations.', 'Inventory management: The practice of managing inventory levels, including tracking stock, forecasting demand, and optimizing storage space.', 'Supplier relationship management: A strategy for building and maintaining positive working relationships with suppliers to ensure quality materials and timely delivery.', 'Quality control: A system of processes and procedures used to ensure products meet customer expectations and industry standards.', 'Root cause analysis: Identifying the underlying causes of problems or defects to prevent them from recurring.', 'Process mapping: Creating visual diagrams to understand and improve complex manufacturing processes, identifying inefficiencies and opportunities for improvement.']
